sentences.sentence: WFP Pakistan and the Government of Khyber Pakhtunkhwa (GoKP) partner to boost girls' education through a cash-based stipend programme.

Islamabad: Today, the Elementary and Secondary Education Department (E&SED), Khyber Pakhtunkhwa (KP) and the United Nations World Food Programme (WFP) signed a Memorandum of Understanding to mark the launch of a cash-based stipend programme for adolescent girls in the Merged Districts (MDs) of KP.
The event, held at Marriot Hotel, was at the invitation of the Secretary, Education Department, Mr. Masood Ahmed and the Representative and Country Director of WFP Pakistan, Ms. Coco Ushiyama.

The Girls' Stipend Programme aims to improve girls' access to and retention in schools, especially at the higher grades where drop-out rates are high, through the provision of income support to the families of adolescent girls.
Over three years of the programme some 30,000 girls in grades 6 -12 in more than 500 government girls' middle and higher schools will receive PKR 1000 per month.
This 3-year programme covering all seven districts and sub-divisions in the merged districts is costed at USD 4.4 million, averaging USD 1.1 million per year.
The Secretary of Education at the official launch of the programme stated, “This intervention lays the foundation stone for our future, especially for under-privileged adolescent girls in MDs.
In today's society, access to quality education is imperative for our successful future”.
He further added that the Government of KP places a high priority in ensuring the access to education enrolment for all out-of-school children.
Currently, there are over 1 million children aged 5 to 16 years who are not enrolled in school in the MDs.
A staggering 67 percent of the population in MDs is unable to read or write, highlighting low performing educational indicators across the MD region.
“ WFP Pakistan's Representative and Country Director, Coco

documents.result_message: Our detector is highly confident that the text is written entirely by a human.
